newsitem.title: USA: Three young people killed in Washington coffee shop.
newsitem.headline: Three young people killed in Washington coffee shop.

text.p: Three young people were found shot to death early Monday in a grisly scene at a fashionable Starbucks coffee shop in Washington's luxury Georgetown area, police said.
Two men aged 18 and 25 and a 24-year-old woman, all with multiple gunshot wounds to the head, were discovered shortly after 5:15 a.m. EDT by an employee arriving for work.
Police shut down busy Wisconsin Avenue, a major traffic artery into downtown Washington and home to exclusive art galleries and upmarket stores, while they investigated the triple homicide.

Sgt. Joe Gentile of the D.C. Metropolitan police, said the three victims were employees of Starbucks, a nationwide coffee shop chain. The store had closed at 8 p.m. Sunday but it was not immediately known when the three died.
Gentile said there were no suspects or possible motives at this time, although local television reported that police had developed the name of a possible suspect.
Starbucks spokesman Dean Torrenga told reporters late Monday the chain had never seen such violence in 26 years of operation.

"In our 26-year history at Starbucks we have never experienced any kind of crime like this," Torrenga said. "We have over 1,200 locations throughout the world...this is the first time it has ever happened and it has touched our lives deeply."
The victims were identified by police as Emory Allen Evans, 25, Aaron David Goodrich, 18, a high school student, and Mary Mahoney, 24, the store's assistant manager.
Local television reported that no money appeared to be missing from the store and said all the doors were locked when the employee who discovered the bodies arrived before dawn.
Each of the victims was shot in the head at least once, according to WRC-TV.
The murders came a day after Washington's Mayor Marion Barry declared the streets of the nation's capital were the safest in the United States.
